The Data object¶

Summary¶

The Data class acts as a data container. It is used by the DNN_likelihood and DNN_likelihood_ensemble objects to manage training/validation/test data through the Data.data_dictionary dictionary. See the documentation of the DNN_likelihood object and the DNN_likelihood_ensemble object for more details on how the Data object is used when building the DNNLikelihood.

Usage¶

We give here a brief introduction to the use of the Data class. Once created, the object is not supposed to be used directly by the used, but it is automatically used by the DNN_likelihood and DNN_likelihood_ensemble objects to manage training/validation/test data. For more details refer to the full class documentation and to the documentation of the DNN_likelihood object and the DNN_likelihood_ensemble object.

The Data object can be directly created from a Sampler object or from input arguments. An example of the first method is given in the Sampler object Usage section of the documentation and consists of the following code:

import DNNLikelihood

sampler = DNNLikelihood.Sampler(new_sampler=False, input_file=<my_output_folder>/toy_sampler)

data = sampler.get_data_object(nsamples=200000, burnin=5000, thin=10, dtype="float64", test_fraction=0)

This gives a Data object with 200000 points which gets automatically stored in the files

  • <my_output_folder>/toy_data.h5

  • <my_output_folder>/toy_data.json

  • <my_output_folder>/toy_data.log

To give an example of the creation of the object from input arguments we first define data arrays (for simplicity we use here 100000 points from the 100000 available in data, the user can use any other data), and then create the object as follows:

data_X = data.data_X[:100000]
data_Y = data.data_Y[:100000]
dtype = ["float64","float32"]

data_new = DNNLikelihood.Data(name = "new_data",
                              data_X = data_X,
                              data_Y = data_Y,
                              dtype = ["float64","float32"],
                              pars_pos_poi = [0],
                              pars_pos_nuis = None,
                              pars_labels = None,
                              pars_bounds = None,
                              test_fraction = 0.2,
                              output_folder = <my_output_folder>,
                              input_file = None,
                              verbose = True)

This created the new object data_new and saves it to the files

  • <my_output_folder>/new_data.h5

  • <my_output_folder>/new_data.json

  • <my_output_folder>/new_data.log

See the documentation of the Data.save and of the corresponding methods with a _h5, _json, and _log suffix.

If the name argument is not passed, then one is automatically generated. In the example above we passed a list for the dtype argument, where the first entry represents the data type of the stored data, while the second is the required data type of the train/validation/test data created from the Data object (see below). Concerning the arguments related to parameters, if neither pars_pos_poi nor pars_pos_nuis are specified, then all parameters are assumed to be parameters of interest, while if only one is specified, the other is automatically set. The arguments pars_labels and pars_bounds can be optionally speficied, otherwise they are automatically set (see the full documentation for details). The output_folder is also optional and, if not specified, the output folder will automatically be set to the code execution folder.

The fraction of train/validation vs test sets is specified through the test_fraction, which, in our example, has been set to 0.2. If test_fraction is not specified (default is None), it is automatically set to 0 and no test data will be available. The fraction of train/validation vs test sets can be changed at any time by changing the Data.test_fraction attribute and calling the Data.define_test_fraction method as follows:

data.test_fraction = 0.3
data.define_test_fraction()

This updates the attributes Data.train_range and Data.test_range, used for train/validation/test data generation.

The Data object can also be initialized importing it from saved files. In this case only the input_file argument needs to be specified, while all other arguments are ignored. One could also optionally specify a new output_folder. In case this is not specified, the Likelihood.output_folder attribute from the imported object is used and the object is saved by updating existing files. If a new output_folder is specified, then the whole object is saved to the new location. One could decide, when importing the object, to load all data stored in the Data.input_h5_file into the RAM for faster generation of train/validation/test data by setting to True the argument load_on_RAM. One could specify the option dtype. This will affect neither saved data, nor the Data.dtype_stored, which is read from input files, but will change the value of the Data.dtype_required that will affect the dtype of the generated train/validation/test data. If dtype is not specified, then the attribute Data.dtype_required is set equal to the Data.dtype_stored attribute. Finally, also the argument test_fraction can be specified, which will update the corresponding attribute available from input files. An example of code to create the object from input files is given by:

import DNNLikelihood

data = DNNLikelihood.Data(input_file="<my_output_folder>/new_data",
                          dtype = "float32",
                          load_on_RAM = True
                         )

When the object is imported, the Data.log attribute is updated and saved in the corresponding file Data.output_log_file.

Data stored in the object can be accessed from the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y attributes as follows:

data.data_X

>>> array([[-0.27304407, -0.46952336,  0.02573462, ..., -0.50863902, -1.12434653,  0.03133135],
           ...,
           [-0.1232975 ,  0.44791999, -0.21759863, ..., -1.04695986, -1.5426192 , -0.21464772]])

data.data_Y

>>> array([-58.52285607, -51.57067745, -52.23295711, ..., -52.55021968, -53.44788316, -54.33490431])

Upon creation of the Data object, the Data.data_dictionary dictionary is initialized as an empyt dictionary containing empty numpy arrays with the correct dtype:

data.data_dictionary

>>> {'X_train': array([], shape=(1, 0), dtype=float32),
     'Y_train': array([], dtype=float32),
     'X_val': array([], shape=(1, 0), dtype=float32),
     'Y_val': array([], dtype=float32),
     'X_test': array([], shape=(1, 0), dtype=float32),
     'Y_test': array([], dtype=float32),
     'idx_train': array([], dtype=int32),
     'idx_val': array([], dtype=int32),
     'idx_test': array([], dtype=int32)}

Such dictionary is updated any time data are generated or updated. For instance, we could generate 10000 train, 5000 validation, and 5000 test points as follows:

data.generate_train_data(npoints_train=10000, npoints_val=5000, seed=1)
data.generate_test_data(npoints_test=5000)

data.data_dictionary

>>> {'X_train': array([[-2.8694883e-01,  4.3361101e-01, -4.6597528e-01, ..., -9.9797267e-01, -9.8734242e-01, -9.5092475e-01],
                        ...,
                       [-4.1338271e-01, -2.6408151e-01,  4.8945403e-01, ..., -7.6410377e-01, -1.5141882e+00, -4.5764816e-01]], dtype=float32),
     'Y_train': array([-52.884396, -55.569386, -54.26178 , ..., -52.6744  , -57.04926 , -55.466824], dtype=float32),
     'X_val':   array([[ 0.19161688, -0.45214146, -0.10997196, ..., -0.86869633, -1.1265236 ,  0.6219092 ],
                        ...,
                       [-0.46064648,  0.5269843 ,  0.19721822, ..., -0.47361913, -0.27832463, -0.06421166]], dtype=float32),
     'Y_val':   array([-53.06865 , -53.42976 , -51.243603, ..., -55.466824, -54.91352 , -50.538002], dtype=float32),
     'X_test':  array([[-0.75995547,  0.49505967,  0.58410156, ..., -1.2593005 , -0.32470152,  0.8180257 ],
                        ...,
                       [-0.79108167,  0.7511644 ,  0.51859653, ..., -0.10589346, 1.1247568 ,  0.6004382 ]], dtype=float32),
     'Y_test':  array([-52.339706, -53.3896  , -55.370182, ..., -53.374393, -53.940056, -53.93778 ], dtype=float32),
     'idx_train': array([   10,    12,    19, ..., 69991, 69993, 69996]),
     'idx_val': array([   14,    67,    74, ..., 69946, 69987, 69998]),
     'idx_test': array([70000, 70001, 70002, ..., 74997, 74998, 74999])}

Where we have also print the new value of the Data.data_dictionary attribute. In the generation of train/validation data one can profit of the seed option to make the process reproducible. Indeed this initializes the numpy random state to seed every time before selecting and splitting data. Concerning test data, these are always generated deterministically by taking the first npoints_test points in Data.test_range range of data.

If scaling of X or Y data is necessary to train the neural network, one can define StandardScalers with the Data.define_scalers method. For instance, scalers can be defined from the training data generated above with the following code:

data.define_scalers(data.data_dictionary["X_train"], data.data_dictionary["Y_train"], scalerX_bool=True, scalerY_bool=True)

>>> [StandardScaler(copy=True, with_mean=True, with_std=True),
     StandardScaler(copy=True, with_mean=True, with_std=True)]

One could also define weights for data points, that allow to train on weighted data. This is done using the Data.compute_sample_weights method. This method bins data and weights data with the inverse frequency of the bins allowing for an arbitrary exponent. For instance we can compute weights making an histogram with 50 bins and weights equal to the inverse square root of frequencies as follows:

data.compute_sample_weights(data.data_dictionary["Y_train"], nbins=50, power=0.5)

>>> array([0.70231453, 0.89124505, 0.72738372, ..., 0.71332963, 1.16068553, 0.89124505])

Notice that the Data.define_scalers and Data.compute_sample_weights methods return a result and do not set any attribute.

Data in the Data.data_dictionary as well as StandardScalers and sample weights are not stored when saving the Data object, and will only be saved as part of trained models and models ensemble by the DNN_likelihood and DNN_likelihood_ensemble objects. For more details refer to the full class documentation and to the documentation of the DNN_likelihood object and the DNN_likelihood_ensemble object.

Even though the files corresponding to the saved object are usually kept sync with the object state, manual change of some attributes does not update them. Nevertheless, the full object can be saved at any time through

data.save(overwrite=True)

Class¶

class DNNLikelihood.Data(name=None, data_X=None, data_Y=None, dtype=None, pars_pos_poi=None, pars_pos_nuis=None, pars_labels=None, pars_bounds=None, test_fraction=None, load_on_RAM=False, output_folder=None, input_file=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

This class contains the Data object representing the dataset used for training, validating and testing the DNNLikelihood. It can be creaded both feeding X and Y data or by loading an existing Data obkect.

Arguments¶

name¶

Name of the Data object. It is used to build the Data.name attribute.

  • type: str or None

  • default: None

data_X¶

Numpy array containing the X data points. It is used to build the Data.data_X attribute.

  • type: numpy.ndarray or None

  • default: (npoints,ndim)

data_Y¶

Numpy array containing the Y data points. It is used to build the Data.data_Y attribute.

  • type: numpy.ndarray or None

  • default: (npoints,)

dtype¶

The argument has a different meaning when creating the object (input_file is None) and when importing the object from files (input_file is not None) and is used to set the Data.dtype_stored and Data.dtype_required attributes.

  • input_file is None

    It represents the data type of the data that will be saved in the Data.output_h5_file dataset.

  • input_file is None

    It represents the data type required for the generation of train/validation/test datasets (stored in the temporary attribute Data.data_dictionary).

In the case in which, when the object is created, one needs a different dtype for stored data and for the generation of train/validation/test datasets, one can pass a list of two strings corresponding to two dtypes that are assigned to the Data.dtype_stored and Data.dtype_required attributes, respectively. When importing a saved Data object, if a list of two dtypes is passed, then the first is ignored (is always fixed from the saved data) and only the second is assigned to the Data.dtype_required attribute.

  • type: str or list or None

  • shape of list: [,] (first entry for Data.dtype_stored and second entry for Data.dtype_required)

  • default: float64

pars_pos_poi¶

List or numpy array containing the positions in the parameters list of the parameters of interest. It is used to build the Data.pars_pos_poi attribute.

  • type: list or numpy.ndarray

  • shape: (n_poi,)

  • default: None

pars_pos_nuis¶

List or numpy array containing the positions in the parameters list of the nuisance parameters. It is used to build the Data.pars_pos_nuis attribute.

  • type: list or numpy.ndarray

  • shape: (n_nuis,)

  • default: None

pars_labels¶

List containing the parameters names as strings. Parameters labels are always parsed as “raw” strings (like, for instance, r"%s"%pars_labels[0]) and can contain latex expressions that are properly compiled when making plots. It is used to build the Data.pars_labels attribute.

  • type: list

  • shape: [ ]

  • length: n_pars

  • default: None

pars_bounds¶

List or numpy array containing containing bounds for the parameters. It is used to build the Data.pars_bounds attribute.

  • type: numpy.ndarray or None

  • shape: (n_pars,2)

  • default: None

test_fraction¶

It specifies the fraction of data that is used as test set. It is used to build the Data.test_fraction attribute.

load_on_RAM¶

If True all data available in the HDF5 dataset Dara.input_h5_file are loaded into the RAM for faster generation of train/validation/test data. If False the HDF5 file is open in read mode and train/validation/test data are generated on demand. It is used to build the Data.load_on_RAM attribute.

output_folder¶

Path (either relative to the code execution folder or absolute) where output files are saved. It is used to set the Data.output_folder attribute.

  • type: str or None

  • default: None

input_file¶

File name (either relative to the code execution folder or absolute, with or without any of the .json or .h5 extensions) of a saved Data object. It is used to set the Data.input_file attribute.

  • type: str or None

  • default: None

verbose¶

Argument used to set the verbosity mode of the Data.__init__ method and the default verbosity mode of all class methods that accept a verbose argument. See Verbosity mode.

  • type: bool

  • default: True

Attributes¶

DNNLikelihood.Data.data_X¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument data_X and containing a numpy array with the X data points.

  • type: numpy.ndarray

  • default: (npoints,ndim)

DNNLikelihood.Data.data_Y¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument data_X and containing a numpy array with the x data points.

  • type: numpy.ndarray

  • default: (npoints,ndim)

DNNLikelihood.Data.data_dictionary¶

Dictionary used by the DNN_likelihood and DNN_likelihood_ensemble objects to keep track and store on the RAM the generated train/validation/test data (used, for instance, when training the DNNLikelihood and in making predictions). The dictionary is updated each time data are generated or updated and is not stored when saving the object (data indices only are stored with trained models by the DNN_likelihood and DNN_likelihood_ensemble objects). See the DNN_likelihood object and the DNN_likelihood_ensemble object objects for more information.

  • type: dict with the following structure:

    • “X_train” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype equal to Data.dtype_required)

      Numpy array with current training dataset X points.

    • “Y_train” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype equal to Data.dtype_required)

      Numpy array with current training dataset Y points.

    • “X_val” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype equal to Data.dtype_required)

      Numpy array with current validation dataset X points.

    • “Y_val” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype equal to Data.dtype_required)

      Numpy array with current validation dataset Y points.

    • “X_test” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype equal to Data.dtype_required)

      Numpy array with current test dataset X points.

    • “Y_test” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype equal to Data.dtype_required)

      Numpy array with current test dataset Y points.

    • “idx_train” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype int32)

      Numpy array with the indices of the training points inside Data.data_X and Data.data_Y.

    • “idx_val” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype int32)

      Numpy array with the indices of the validation points inside Data.data_X and Data.data_Y.

    • “idx_test” (value type: numpy.ndarray with dtype int32)

      Numpy array with the indices of the test points inside Data.data_X and Data.data_Y.

DNNLikelihood.Data.dtype_stored¶

Data type of the dataset stored in the Data.output_h5_file. It is set to the value of the dtype input argument if not None and to "float64" if None the first time the object is created and remains unchanged when saving/loading the Data object.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.dtype_required¶

Required data type for the generation of the train/validation/test datasets. The attribute is always set to the value of the dtype input argument if not None and to "float64" if None. It represents the data type of the data stored in the attribute Data.data_dictionary.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.generic_pars_labels¶

List containing parameters names automatically generated by the function utils.define_generic_pars_labels. All parameters of interest are named r"$\theta_{i}$" with i ranging between one to the number of parameters of interest and all nuisance parameters are named r"$\nu_{j}$" with j ranging between one to the number of nuisance parameters. Parameters labels are always used as “raw” strings (like, for instance, r"%s"%generic_pars_labels[0]) and can contain latex expressions that are properly compiled when making plots.

  • type: list

  • shape: [ ]

  • length: n_pars

DNNLikelihood.Data.input_file¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument input_file. Whenever this attribute is not None, it is used to reconstructed the object from input files (see the Data.__init__ method for details).

  • type: str or None

DNNLikelihood.Data.input_h5_file¶

Absolute path to the .h5 file containing saved Data HDF5 (see the Data.save_h5 method for details). It is automatically generated from the attribute Data.input_file. When the latter is None, the attribute is set to None.

  • type: str or None

DNNLikelihood.Data.input_json_file¶

Absolute path to the .json file containing saved Data json (see the Data.save_json method for details). It is automatically generated from the attribute Data.input_file. When the latter is None, the attribute is set to None.

  • type: str or None

DNNLikelihood.Data.input_log_file¶

Absolute path to the .log file containing saved Data log (see the Data.save_log method for details). It is automatically generated from the attribute Data.input_file. When the latter is None, the attribute is set to None.

  • type: str or None

DNNLikelihood.Data.load_on_RAM¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument load_on_RAM. If True all data available in the HDF5 dataset Dara.input_h5_file are loaded into the RAM for faster generation of train/validation/test data. If False the HDF5 file is open in read mode and train/validation/test data are generated on demand.

  • type: str or None

DNNLikelihood.Data.log¶

Dictionary containing a log of the Data object calls. The dictionary has datetime strings as keys and actions as values. Actions are also dictionaries, containing details of the methods calls.

  • type: dict

  • keys: datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S.%fZ")[:-3]

  • values: dict with the following structure:

    • “action” (value type: str)

      Short description of the action. possible values: "created", "loaded", "saved", "updated data dictionary", "computed sample weights", "defines scalers".

    • “data” (value type: list of str)

      List of keys of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary corresponding to values (data) that have been updated.

    • “npoints train” (value type: int)

      Number of training points available in the updated Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

    • “npoints val” (value type: int)

      Number of validation points available in the updated Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

    • “npoints test” (value type: int)

      Number of test points available in the updated Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

    • “scaler X” (value type: bool)

      When defining scalars it indicates if X points have been scaled.

    • “scaler Y” (value type: bool)

      When defining scalars it indicates if Y points have been scaled.

    • “file name” (value type: str)

      File name of file involved in the action.

    • “file path” (value type: str)

      Path of file involved in the action.

    • “files names” (value type: list of str)

      List of file names of files involved in the action.

    • “files paths” (value type: list of str)

      List of paths of files involved in the action.

DNNLikelihood.Data.name¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument name and containing the name of the Data object. If None is passed, then name is assigned the value model_" + datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S.%fZ")[:-3]+"_data", while if a string is passed, the "_data" suffix is appended (preventing duplication if it is already present). It is used to generate output files names.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.ndims¶

Number of dimensions of the X data (i.e. number of parameters entering in the logpdf). It is automatically set to the length of the first point in the input argument data_X.

  • type: int

DNNLikelihood.Data.npoints¶

Number of X/Y data. It is automatically set to the length of the the input argument data_X.

  • type: int

DNNLikelihood.Data.opened_dataset¶

Opened HDF5 dataset. When importing data with the Data.load_on_RAM attribute set to False the HDF5 dataset is kept open until it is manually close with the Data.close_opened_dataset method.

  • type: HDF5 file object

DNNLikelihood.Data.output_folder¶

Absolute path corresponding to the input argument output_folder. If the latter is None, then Data.output_folder is set to the code execution folder. If the folder does not exist it is created by the utils.check_create_folder function.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.output_h5_file¶

Absolute path to the .h5 dataset file where the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y attributes are saved (see the Data.save_log method for details). It is automatically generated from the Data.output_folder and Data.name attributes.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.output_json_file¶

Absolute path to the .json file where part of the Data object is saved (see the Sampler.save_json method for details). It is automatically generated from the Data.output_folder and Data.name attributes.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.output_log_file¶

Absolute path to the .log file where the Data.log attribute is saved (see the Data.save_log method for details). It is automatically generated from the Sampler.output_folder and Sampler.name attributes.

  • type: str

DNNLikelihood.Data.pars_bounds¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument pars_bounds and containing a numpy array with the parameters bounds. If the input argument is None then bounds for all parameters are set to [-np.inf,np.inf].

  • type: numpy.ndarray

  • shape: (n_pars,2)

DNNLikelihood.Data.pars_labels¶

List corresponding to the input argument pars_labels. If the input argument is None then Data.pars_labels is set equal to the automatically generated Data.generic_pars_labels. Parameters labels are always parsed as “raw” strings (like, for instance, r"%s"%pars_labels[0]) and can contain latex expressions that are properly compiled when making plots.

  • type: list

  • shape: [ ]

  • length: n_pars

DNNLikelihood.Data.pars_pos_nuis¶

Numpy array corresponding to the input argument pars_pos_nuis.

  • type: list or `numpy.ndarray

  • shape: (n_nuis,)

DNNLikelihood.Data.pars_pos_poi¶

Numpy array corresponding to the input argument pars_pos_poi.

  • type: list or `numpy.ndarray

  • shape: (n_poi,)

DNNLikelihood.Data.test_fraction¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument test_fraction. It specifies the fraction of data that is used as test set. The first (1-test_fraction) fraction of points will be used to generate train and validation data while the remaining test_fraction to generate test data.

DNNLikelihood.Data.test_range¶

Attribute set from the Data.test_fraction attribute and containing the range of test data indices in the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y numpy arrays.

DNNLikelihood.Data.train_range¶

Attribute set from the Data.test_fraction attribute and containing the range of train/validation data indices in the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y numpy arrays.

DNNLikelihood.Data.verbose¶

Attribute corresponding to the input argument verbose. It represents the verbosity mode of the Data.__init__ method and the default verbosity mode of all class methods that accept a verbose argument. See Verbosity mode.

  • type: bool or int

Methods¶

Data.__init__(name=None, data_X=None, data_Y=None, dtype=None, pars_pos_poi=None, pars_pos_nuis=None, pars_labels=None, pars_bounds=None, test_fraction=None, load_on_RAM=False, output_folder=None, input_file=None, verbose=True)[source]¶

The Data object can be initialized in two different ways, depending on the value of the input_file argument.

  • input_file is None (default)

    All other arguments are parsed and saved in corresponding attributes. If no name is given, then one is created. The object is saved upon creation through the Data.save method.

  • input_file is not None

    The object is reconstructed from the input files through the private method Data.__load. If the load_on_RAM argument is True, then all samples are loaded into RAM, otherwise the dataset is kept open and data are retrieved on demand. If the input argument output_folder is None (default), the attribute Data.output_folder is set from the input file, otherwise it is set to the input argument.

  • Arguments

    See class Arguments documentation.

  • Produces file

    • Data.output_log_file

    • Data.output_json_file

    • Data.output_h5_file (only if input_file is None)

Data._Data__check_define_input_files()¶

Sets the attributes corresponding to input files Data.input_h5_file, Data.input_json_file, and Data.input_log_file depending on the value of the Data.input_file attribute.

Data._Data__check_define_output_files()¶

Sets the attributes corresponding to output files Data.output_h5_file, Data.output_json_file, Data.output_log_file depending on the value of the Data.input_file and Data.output_folder attributes.

Data._Data__check_define_name()¶

Private method that defines the Data.name attribute. If Data.name is None it replaces it with "model_"+datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S.%fZ")[:-3]+"_data", otherwise it appends the suffix “_data” (preventing duplication if it is already present).

Data._Data__check_define_data(verbose=None)¶

Checks that data_X and data_Y have the same length, sets the data type attributes Data.dtype_required and Data.dtype_stored (defaults “float64”), and converts Data.data_X and Data.data_Y into the dtype corresponding to Data.dtype_stored.

Data._Data__check_define_pars(verbose=None)¶

Private method that checks the consistency of the Data.pars_pos_nuis, Data.pars_pos_poi, Data.pars_labels, and Data.pars_bounds attributes and converts Data.pars_pos_nuis, Data.pars_pos_poi, and and Data.pars_bounds to numpy arrays. If no parameters positions are specified, all parameters are assumed to be parameters of interest. If only the position of the parameters of interest or of the nuisance parameters is specified, the other is automatically generated by matching dimensions. If labels are not provided then Data.pars_labels is set to the value of Data.generic_pars_labels. If parameters bounds are not provided, they are set to (-np.inf,np.inf). A check is performed on the length of the four attributes and an Exception is raised if the length does not match Data.ndims.

  • Arguments

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data._Data__load(verbose=None)¶

Private method used by the Data.__init__ one to import a previously saved Data object from the files Data.input_json_file, Data.input_json_file and Data.input_h5_file. If Data.load_on_RAM is True, then all samples are loaded into RAM, otherwise the dataset is kept open and data are retrieved on demand.

  • Arguments

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data._Data__define_test_fraction()¶

Private method that sets the Data.test_fraction attribute and from this the two attributes Data.train_range and Data.test_range, containing the range of indices of Data.data_X and Data.data_Y corresponding to the train (and validation) and test sets.

Data.define_test_fraction(verbose=None)[source]¶

Method analog to the private method Data.__define_test_fraction useful to change the available fraction of train/valifation vs test data. Differently from the analog private method, this one updates the files corresponding to the Data.output_json_file and Data.output_log_file attributes.

  • Arguments

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

  • Produces file

    • Data.output_log_file

    • Data.output_json_file

Data.close_opened_dataset(verbose=None)[source]¶

Closes the opened h5py datasets Data.opened_dataset.

  • Arguments

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.save_log(overwrite=False, verbose=None)[source]¶

Saves the content of the Data.log attribute in the file Data.output_log_file

This method is called by the methods

  • Data.__init__ with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub if Data.input_file is not None, and with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub otherwise

  • Data.save with overwrite=overwrite and verbose=verbose

  • Data.generate_train_indices with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.generate_train_data with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.update_train_indices with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.update_train_data with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.generate_test_indices with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.generate_test_data with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.compute_sample_weights with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

  • Data.define_scalers with overwrite=True and verbose=verbose_sub

This method is called by the Data.save method to save the entire object.

  • Arguments

    • overwrite

      If True if a file with the same name already exists, then it gets overwritten. If False is a file with the same name already exists, then the old file gets renamed with the utils.check_rename_file function.

      • type: bool

      • default: False

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

  • Produces file

    • Data.output_log_file

Data.save_json(overwrite=False, verbose=True)[source]¶

Data objects are saved to three files: a .json, a .log, and an .h5, corresponding to the three attributes Data.output_json_file, Data.output_log_file, and Data.output_h5_file. See the Data.save method documentation for the list of saved attributes.

This method is called by the Data.save method to save the entire object.

  • Arguments

    • overwrite

      If True if a file with the same name already exists, then it gets overwritten. If False is a file with the same name already exists, then the old file gets renamed with the utils.check_rename_file function.

      • type: bool

      • default: False

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

  • Produces file

    • Data.output_json_file

Data.save_h5(overwrite=False, verbose=None)[source]¶

Data objects are saved to three files: a .json, a .log, and an .h5, corresponding to the three attributes Data.output_json_file, Data.output_log_file, and Data.output_h5_file. See the Data.save method documentation for the list of saved attributes.

This method saves the .h5 file as an h5py dataset containing the attributes Data.data_X and Data.data_Y, and an additional entry with the shape of the former.

This method is called by the Data.save method to save the entire object.

  • Arguments

    • overwrite

      If True if a file with the same name already exists, then it gets overwritten. If False is a file with the same name already exists, then the old file gets renamed with the utils.check_rename_file function.

      • type: bool

      • default: False

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

  • Produces file

    • Data.output_h5_file

Data.generate_train_indices(npoints_train, npoints_val, seed, verbose=None)[source]¶

Method used to generate npoints_train train and npoints_val validation data indices (integer positions in the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y arrays). It updates the "idx_train" and "idx_val" items of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

  • Arguments

    • npoints_train

      Required number of training points.

      • type: int

    • npoints_val

      Required number of validation points.

      • type: int

    • seed

      Seed of the random number generator. It is used to initialize the numpy random state.

      • type: int

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.generate_train_data(npoints_train, npoints_val, seed, verbose=None)[source]¶

Method used to generate npoints_train train and npoints_val validation data. In order to extract the required number of points from the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y arrays (which may not be available on RAM), it first generates indices with the Data.generate_train_indices method and then slices the data with the generated indices. It updates the "X_train", "Y_train", "X_val" and "Y_val" items of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

  • Arguments

    • npoints_train

      Required number of training points.

      • type: int

    • npoints_val

      Required number of validation points.

      • type: int

    • seed

      Seed of the random number generator. It is used to initialize the numpy random state.

      • type: int

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.update_train_indices(npoints_train, npoints_val, seed, verbose=None)[source]¶

Analog of Data.generate_train_indices, but it only updates indices adding more points if any are already available in the Data.data_dictionary dictionary. It updates the "idx_train" and "idx_val" items of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

  • Arguments

    • npoints_train

      Required number of training points.

      • type: int

    • npoints_val

      Required number of validation points.

      • type: int

    • seed

      Seed of the random number generator. It is used to initialize the numpy random state.

      • type: int

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.update_train_data(npoints_train, npoints_val, seed, verbose=None)[source]¶

Analog of Data.generate_train_indices, but it only updates data adding more points if any are already available in the Data.data_dictionary dictionary. It updates the "X_train", "Y_train", "X_val" and "Y_val" items of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

  • Arguments

    • npoints_train

      Required number of training points.

      • type: int

    • npoints_val

      Required number of validation points.

      • type: int

    • seed

      Seed of the random number generator. It is used to initialize the numpy random state.

      • type: int

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.generate_test_indices(npoints_test, verbose=None)[source]¶

Method used to generate npoints_test test data indices (integer positions in the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y arrays). Test indices are always generated deterministically and always represent the first npoints_test in the Dara.test_range range. It updates the "idx_test" item of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

  • Arguments

    • npoints_test

      Required number of test points.

      • type: int

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.generate_test_data(npoints_test, verbose=None)[source]¶

Method used to generate npoints_test test data indices (integer positions in the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y arrays). In order to extract the required number of points from the Data.data_X and Data.data_Y arrays (which may not be available on RAM), it first generates indices with the Data.generate_test_indices method and then slices the data with the generated indices. Test data are always generated deterministically and always correspond to the first npoints_test in the Dara.test_range range of Data.data_X and Data.data_Y. It updates the "X_test" and "Y_test" items of the Data.data_dictionary dictionary.

  • Arguments

    • npoints_test

      Required number of test points.

      • type: int

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

Data.compute_sample_weights(sample, nbins=100, power=1, verbose=None)[source]¶

Method that computes weights of points given their distribution. Sample weights are used to weigth data as a function of their frequency, obtained by binning the data in nbins and assigning weight equal to the inverse of the bin count to the power power. In order to avoid too large weights for bins with very few counts, all bins with less than 5 counts are assigned frequency equal to 1/5 to the power power.

  • Arguments

    • sample

      Distribution of points that need to be weighted.

      • type: numpy.ndarray

      • shape: (len(sample),)

    • nbins

      Number of bins to histogram the sample data

      • type: int

      • default: 100

    • power

      Exponent of the inverse of the bin count used to assign weights.

      • type: float

      • default: 1

    • verbose

      Verbosity mode. See the Verbosity mode documentation for the general behavior.

      • type: bool

      • default: None

  • Returns

    Numpy array of the same length of sample containing the required weights.

    • type: numpy.ndarray

    • shape: (len(sample),)

Data.define_scalers(data_X, data_Y, scalerX_bool, scalerY_bool, verbose=None)[source]¶

Method that defines StandardScalers fit to the data_X and data_Y data. Scalers are defined based in the boolean flags scalerX_bool and scalerY_bool. When the flags are false the scalers are defined with the arguemtns with_mean=False and with_std=False which correspond to identity transformations.

  • Arguments

    • data_X

      X data to fit the StandardScaler scalerX.

      • type: numpy.ndarray

      • shape: (npoints,ndim)

    • data_Y

      Y data to fit the StandardScaler scalerY.

      • type: numpy.ndarray

      • shape: (npoints,)

    • scalerX_bool

      If true the X scaler is fit to the data_X data, otherwise it is set to the identity transformation.

      • type: bool

    • scalerY_bool

      If true the Y scaler is fit to the data_Y data, otherwise it is set to the identity transformation.

      • type: bool

  • Returns

    List of the form [scalerX,scalerY] containing the X and Y scalers.

    • type: list

    • shape: [scalerX,scalerY]
